title: Slows and mobility, why not have slows root if they exceed a certain cap ?
body:
Slows already stack with a deminished rate, they are widely available from 10% ({{champion:64}} & {{champion:35}}  E rank 1) to 65% ( {{champion:21}} & {{champion:72}} E rank 5 )

There are champions with stronger slows like {{champion:412}} R ( 99% ) {{champion:201}} Q ( 70% ) {{champion:75}}  W ( up to 95% rank 5 ) but they are rare in general and can have special tweeks as needed.

What if, when a champion is slowed for above 75% they are rooted for half the remaining duration?

That seems like an amazing solution to mobility creep which does not fk over immobile champions at the same time, especially because of the availability of tenacity.

So when {{champion:161}} slows a target with his rank 3 Q [1.5s duration], then {{champion:22}} follows up with Frost Shots, the target is rooted for 0.75 seconds, consuming {{champion:161}} 's Q debuff.



-_-




Edit 1: the most straightforward way to give counterplay for massive slows like {{champion:75}} & {{champion:26}} is not allowing movespeed roots to happen from a single debuff. Maintaining the 90% slows until a teammate slows the target.

-_-

Edit 2: examples of the formula's implication to clarify: {{champion:29}} casts a rank 5 W on a target, he then auto attacks the target while he has a {{item:3022}}. The calculation to determine the root goes as follows: W = 45% slow debuff, {{item:3022}} = 30% slow debuff. 45% + 30% = 75%. 75% > 75% FALSE. 

Therefore the target is slowed as on live.

another example with a stronger slow: {{champion:21}} casts a rank 5 E on a target, she then auto attacks the target while she has an {{item:3025}}. The calculation to determine the root gives: E = 65% + {{item:3025}} = 30%. 65% + 30% = 95% > 75% TRUE, MERGE DEBUFFS INTO ROOT. USE LAST APPLIED DEBUFF.

Therefore using the duration of {{item:3025}}, the target is rooted for .75 seconds.

-_-

Edit 3: created a post in the comments mentioning champions that can have abuse cases with the system, upvote so everyone can see :)



-_-



**CLARITY**: in order for players to understand and take advantage of proposed formula, a small visual change must be done.

Currently on live, when a champion is slowed they leave **Yellow tracks** beneath them as they walk. This formula can be further improved by changing the color of the tracks to **Red** when a target is "_Critically Slowed_", meaning that they have a 40%+ slow debuff applied to them.

This way both the slower and the slowed target understand that a root can be performed with a good slow followup.

replies.body: Why not just have slows reduce the speed of dashes? One of the big advantages of gapclosers in fights is that they grant temporary immunity to most kinds of CC, and having crowd control affect them as they would normal movement would allow champions dependent on their own crowd control to use it more reliably. Stacking slows into roots would give anyone with soft CC the ability to transition to hard CC, which has a completely different set of gameplay implications (soft CC only reduces movement, hard CC denies movement options outright).

Doing this requires a ton of animation work, isn't visually clean, and just makes the game clunkier without much actual gain in terms of counterplay. 

I mean, let's say J4 is ulting you. Do you really think that slowing him mid gap closer will make a difference in whether you live or die? He's still jumping on top of you regardless of whether he's slowed or not, it just takes like 3 frames longer and looks jankier if you slow him mid jump. 

Gap closers are so fast in general (in fact, that's the freaking point of them, they're faster than walking) that reducing their speed with slows would require an incredible amount of skill to do on reaction and only slow them down by a few frames. All this change would do is make the game clunkier without actually solving the issues you're unhappy with.

I agree, having slows affect dashes would require dash animations to be fluid regardless of their speed, but then again, we have attack speed and movement speed in the game, both of which affect character animations, along with dashes that already scale with movement speed (on {{champion:54}}  and {{champion:157}} ). I also think that would offer valid opportunities for counterplay. Suppose you dash through a pool of Mega Adhesive or Glacial Storm: right now, you'd dash through them as if they didn't exist, but with the above change you'd be affected by the slow as you'd pass through it, which would reinforce the role of both those objects as persistent zones of crowd control. You'd be able to use the extra time offered by a slowed dash to jump out of the way (if they're dashing towards you) or catch up to them (if they're dashing away from you). I don't think Cataclysm is a good counter-example to this because {{champion:59}} is immune to crowd control while using it anyways. By contrast, {{champion:429}} would be a great example of how such a change could allow for more consistency: right now, her infinite dashes allow her to completely ignore slows when in effect, which makes her a pain to deal with when you're a kiteable champion with only soft CC ({{champion:2}}, for example). Having slows affect her Martial Poise would allow for CC to interact better with her, and offer low-mobility champions more opportunities to catch up to her.

In the end, gapclosers are basically another form of movement with a few cool bonuses (you get to move over walls and sometimes other units). Temporary CC immunity shouldn't be one of those bonuses, especially since it's applied pretty inconsistently (why is displacement the only form of crowd control that affects dashes?). Slowing someone mid-dash should offer feedback immediately, rather than after the dash ends, and would reduce the stigma of dashes as get-out-of-jail-free cards in fights against less mobile opponents.

I think what you mentioned is a good idea, but it will have to slow speed of dashes significantly for it to be meaningful counterplay.

MS has a soft and hard cap in both directions.  you could have 350 base MS and get a 100% MS increase.  But you won't have 700 MS; it would hit the soft cap, and get reduced, and then hit the hard cap, and get reduced even further.

Same goes for slows.  It will reduce you MS, but you will never see anyone go below ~80MS.  And, I'm pretty sure that multiple slows stack multaplicitive, not additive, so its not 70%+15%=85%.  Its 70%*1.15= 80.5%

Still funny tho.   Especially mobility creep {{item:3070}} {{champion:22}} {{item:3070}}

If this did get implemented, I feel it would be best if you needed at least two *champions*, not two slow sources. With a high-rank Wither and an Iceborn Gauntlet, {{champion:75}} could simply W someone and AA them and suddenly they'd be stuck. Not to mention the abuse cases with {{champion:68}}, whose lack of hard CC is one of his main draws (and the reason I almost always get Rylai's on him).

Relying on an ally to synchronize it would reward teamwork and not just slow-stacking in your build.

The answer is simple.

If Riot wants a champion to be able to root people, they give them a root. If they want them to slow people, they give them a slow. If Riot wanted Nasus, Thresh (Thresh here is particularly problematic, because he already has 2 slows in his kit), and Zilean to be rooting people, they would've given them roots.

Riot has also explained previously that slows are a good way to add power to a champions kit with a low chance of making that champion overbearing. If slows could suddenly root (and thus were made more powerful), they would have to retune and rebalance so many champions around this new mechanic that it just wouldn't be worth it.

This is not a champion scale problem, this is large scale system of abuse. Many champions existed in the game prior to the mobility creep problem {{champion:34}} {{champion:22}} {{champion:40}} {{champion:69}} {{champion:36}} {{champion:41}} {{champion:21}} {{champion:20}} {{champion:2}} {{champion:27}} Etc.

Those champion with persistent slows either bullied a class really hard that they couldn't be played against them or need to land skillshots ( which are countered by mobility ) to stick to a target. 

The proposed formula solves the latter issue. Currently {{champion:34}} {{champion:36}} {{champion:2}} for example, slowing a mobile character like {{champion:236}} {{champion:429}} {{champion:7}} {{champion:150}} {{champion:103}} {{champion:105}} {{champion:268}} is irrelevant as they will simply dash away.

Many champions have slows, the slows are rendered useless because of the way mobility works. Meanwhile immobiles die when they are severely slowed. Giving a root without a good condition with meaningful counterplay is not something Riot wants. This is why the roots **require 2** slowing debuffs, **remove** the debuffs and apply **half** the duration.

Very few champions will be outliers and that's fine. Had there been many champions with slows above 75% or more than 1 slow in their kit, the effort would not be worth it ( I doubt there is more than 10 champions like that in the game ). However that is not the case, the solution is at hand and should be taken advantage of.

I think something else interesting would be some slows which got stronger the further the target moves from the place they got slowed (maybe have a pole or something to mark where they got hit by the slow though it isn't really necessary I guess)

This means less mobile champions would be punished less by the slow then more mobile champions (since the less mobile champions are less likely to actually be able to move far away from the starting location)

Well historically mobile characters have been bullying immobile ones more and more every champion release. {{champion:421}} {{champion:429}} {{champion:268}} {{champion:150}} even the supports have mobility spells {{champion:412}} Q W {{champion:201}} W {{champion:432}} E.

A 99% slow doesn't mean nearly as much to a mobile champion as much as it does to an immobile one. However roots put them at an equal footing, which should be the implication of a severe slow.

But a root does mean more to immobile champions than mobile ones as well. A mobile champ can just use their mobility to catch up/escape after the root ends while an immobile one is just as screwed.

Meanwhile, does it trigger at 75% nominal slow or 75% effective slow? I mean, the current formula is some like Effective Slow = 1 - (1- Strongest Slow)*(1-0.35*Slow2)*(1-0.35*Slow3)*... While Nominal Slow = Strongest Slow + Slow2 + Slow3 +... Also, this is ignoring things like how to account for MS boosts (percent and flat), slow removals, and what to do with self slows that would make this difficult to implement consistently.

Anyways, I think that there should be a distinction between slowing someone and rooting them.

The formula consumes the debuffs to create a "Rooted" debuff. For an immobile champion, they can escape using movespeed or escape due to the lack of CC [ it was consumed to create the root ]. A mobile will be forced to sit down, denying them usage of the gapcloser until the duration expires.

Proposed formula ignores effective slow, it works by checking percentage values on debuffs and adding them together to determine whether they're enough to forge a root or not.

Currently, a slowed target shows yellow lines below them to indicate that they're slowed. I suggest that red lines be shown below the target if they're critically slowed ( 40%+ ) for the sake of ally synergy to form a root.
